text: Michael Gove probably has more support than David Lidington across the parliamentary party but a large number of ERG don’t trust either of them. Theresa May is more likely to stand down for Lidington
author: ShippersUnbound

text: Cabinet minister: “The end is nigh. She will be gone in 10 days.”
author: ShippersUnbound

text: May’s u-turns last week destroyed her brand for being steady and reliable. Her genius for 2yrs was to persuade MPs she was on their side. Now no one thinks she is on their side
author: ShippersUnbound

text: May’s husband Philip is still urging her to fight on and the PM has not yet agreed to go but senior aides say he should take a leaf out of Denis Thatcher’s book and urge her to walk away
author: ShippersUnbound

text: May’s chief whip Julian Smith believes she has no prospect of getting her deal through or landing Boris Johnson or Jacob Rees-Mogg unless she agrees to stand down
author: ShippersUnbound

text: Cabinet ministers have turned on May in a spectacular fashion today saying the last week shows her judgment has “gone haywire”. One said she was “erratic” and can’t be trusted
author: ShippersUnbound

text: Despite disagreements over the succession pretty well everyone agrees the PM should go, which should at least ensure that she agrees to name a date
author: ShippersUnbound

text: Michael Gove has been secretly building a leadership campaign team and is willing to become acting prime minister if his colleagues want him. He’s sceptical that Lidington can come up with an acceptable Brexit policy
author: ShippersUnbound

text: Jeremy Hunt does not back Lidington because he thinks he will do a deal with Labour for permanent membership of a customs union
author: ShippersUnbound

text: IMPORTANT: Sajid Javid the Home Secretary is prepared to back Lidington if the other main leadership contenders stand aside but he wouldn’t back Gove or Hunt
author: ShippersUnbound

text: Cabinet coup plotters want to install an interim leader to deliver Brexit. There is good support for David Lidington but others pushing Michael Gove and Jeremy Hunt
author: ShippersUnbound

text: I have spoken to 11 cabinet ministers today who want the prime minister to resign. They will confront her at cabinet on Monday
author: ShippersUnbound

text: BREAKING: A full blown cabinet coup is under way tonight to remove Theresa May as prime minister
author: ShippersUnbound

text: I really would buy tomorrow's Sunday Times. It really is a belter
author: ShippersUnbound

text: seconded

text: Actual genius

author: ShippersUnbound

text: That’s very kind. Hope you like Fall Out too. Volume three taking shape...

text: I’m afraid I’m going to be too busy writing on Saturday to be marching but one of my colleagues will be along to cover it
author: ShippersUnbound

text: Good luck. The historic mess will still be here for you when you feel a bit better

text: Theoretically since I haven’t had time to write most of it because other things keep happening

text: Paul Mason hates cheese. That’s it
author: ShippersUnbound

text: How much longer?
author: ShippersUnbound

text: May’s statement, a bit like her deal, was fine within the parameters she set herself. The problem is that she seldom allows herself to do anything that truly changes the narrative or the rules of the game
author: ShippersUnbound

text: May’s statement based very heavily on No10 polling showing that even leave voters want an end to parliamentary bickering and get on with Brexit. But was it enough to rouse them to badger MPs into backing her?
author: ShippersUnbound

text: Now if Theresa May comes out in a ball gown to disco lights and does a John Travolta-style dance singing “nothing has changed” I for one will applaud
author: ShippersUnbound

text: Which party leader would you like to see the back of?
author: ShippersUnbound

text: Think of all the interesting things Theresa May could say this evening. Then think of something else. That.
author: ShippersUnbound

text: It's all going very well
author: ShippersUnbound

text: Vince Cable states that Corbyn walked out of meeting with May because the independent group were present
author: ShippersUnbound

text: Great news, Giles. You beat us to a name...
author: ShippersUnbound

text: Totally agree. You walk out of Labour, the party you left is entitled to get its seats back. Defection isn't cost free. Organise, get more defectors, become bigger, then get your sets back. Simples (as someone said)
author: ShippersUnbound

text: A very sensible take on the Bercow business https://capx.co/bercow-brext-and-the-battle-for-sovereignty/?omhide=true&utm_source=CapX+briefing&utm_campaign=83d0d8c699-EMAIL_CAMPAIGN_2017_07_17_COPY_02&utm_medium=email&utm_term=0_b5017135a0-83d0d8c699-241784877 … from @alexmassie

text: “I know you attach great weight to what you think,” says Bercow, redefining the dictionary definition of chutzpah
author: ShippersUnbound

text: Something in this
author: ShippersUnbound

text: The only way this makes any sense is if the ERG vote to bring down the govt in a confidence motion as May and the rest of the Commons will reverse the March 29 departure date. There can’t be no deal with her in charge
author: ShippersUnbound

text: Thanks to whoever came up with #erskinemayhem. A perfect chapter title for Brexit Book 3
author: ShippersUnbound

text: ERG praising Bercow might as well jump in the cooking pot wearing a Christmas hat and say "gobble, gobble"
author: ShippersUnbound

text: You don't appear to have read the tweet. He tore it up previously to suspend the standing orders. Now he's making a virtue of a highly vigorous interpretation of the rules
author: ShippersUnbound

text: not a Tory or a Brexiteer
author: ShippersUnbound

text: Revenge served bone dry, May advised Osborne to "go away and get to know the party better" when she sacked him
author: ShippersUnbound

text: He clearly changed the rules before. This is probably right but it's not exactly helping the house arrive at a conclusion
author: ShippersUnbound

text: Bercow threatens to block the 3rd/4th meaningful votes. Says government "cannot legitimately submit to the house" a proposition that is substantially similar. Having torn up the rule book to thwart the govt, he is now pledging to stick rigorously to it to thwart the govt
author: ShippersUnbound

text: Well fancy that

text: Thanks!

text: How covering Brexit is like dealing with a new baby. My piece for the Sunday Times magazine piece about my pretty mega month

text: The great @alexmassie and @jmullinjourno are arguably my two favourite Scotsmen. Here they perfectly encapsulate the breadth of weary humour that makes that nation great. I genuinely wish them well for the second half

text: I do, but I was the first person in my family to go to university, I knew no one in politics or journalism when I began. I had no patrons to give me jobs. I don't feel anything has been handed to me on a plate

text: I'm very glad other people march, if it helps them to let off steam. The right to protest is central to democracy. Just never been so moved myself

text: Marches made no difference to the Iraq War or, I suspect, to Brexit

text: I'm just saying I've never been moved to do it

text: And arguably that doesn’t get you elected or change anything either

text: You seem more optimistic than @alexmassie or did you start on the sauce earlier?

text: The urge to march for things and against things is one I have never understood. Why not write a letter instead?

text: In which Brexiteers, who don't trust the prime minister or believe she is strong, continue to believe that a leader who cannot control her own cabinet has the strength to defy parliament and the EU and deliver a no deal Brexit. Perhaps she is Boudicca after all
author: ShippersUnbound
